Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose true identity in refugee claim
Crimes.Violation_Type: Unauthorized stay and false identity in claim
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reviewable error in assessing establishment and hardship under section 25 of IRPA
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 25
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant lived in Canada without status for years, had ties but no exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review and re-determination of H&C application
Crimes.Court_Ruling: Application granted, decision remitted for reconsideration
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicant without legal status in Canada
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Failed to disclose true identity in initial refugee claim
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Unusual or disproportionate hardship if removed to Ivory Coast
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard focusing on justification, transparency, and intelligibility
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Personal hardship versus generalized country conditions
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Misapplication of refugee-like risk assessment in H&C context
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Length of stay, family and community ties in Canada, country condition reports
Crimes.Application_Basis: Humanitarian and Compassionate grounds due to long unauthorized stay
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Ties to Canada and personal circumstances in home country
Crimes.Relief_Sought: H&C relief allowing stay in Canada
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Section 25 allows H&C relief based on exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Officer failed to assess individualized hardship
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Flawed due to reliance on generalized risk
Crimes.Cause_Description: False identity claim led to unauthorized stay and H&C application
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Incomplete consideration of personal hardship factors
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Generalized risk improperly substituted for personal hardship analysis
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Yes – failure to disclose true identity
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of immigration officer under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Error in applying refugee determination logic to H&C assessment
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to consider applicant’s specific circumstances

Crimes.Dispute_Type: H&C application denial due to misrepresentation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reviewable errors in establishment and hardship assessment under IRPA s.25
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 25
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Questioned due to unauthorized status and prior missteps
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, country condition reports, personal ties documentation
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Hardship due to Canadian ties and instability in Ivory Coast
Crimes.Evaluation_Standard: Reasonableness for factual findings, correctness for legal interpretation
Crimes.Application_Error: Use of generalized risk instead of personal hardship
Crimes.Application_Factor: Long residence in Canada without status
Crimes.Decision_Review_Issue: Misapplication of legal test for hardship
Crimes.Cause_of_Refusal: Focus on unauthorized status and generalized country risks
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to engage with personal evidence of hardship
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Not applicable – issue was misrepresentation by omission
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Improper standard applied in hardship assessment
Crimes.Omission_Type: Failure to disclose full personal circumstances

Crimes.Dispute_Type: H&C application denial due to alleged misrepresentation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reviewable error in hardship assessment under IRPA s.25
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 25
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Impacted by unauthorized stay and prior denials
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Personal affidavits, community ties, country condition reports
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Hardship due to long absence from Ivory Coast and integration in Canada
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Personal hardship vs. generalized country conditions
Crimes.Application_Error: Applied refugee-like 'generalized risk' test in H&C context
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Evidence of personal hardship and Canadian establishment
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Reasonableness standard applies to factual assessments
Crimes.Application_Factor: Years of unauthorized stay and familial ties in Canada
Crimes.Credibility_Issues: Linked to history of unauthorized status
Crimes.Omission_Type: Failure to fully disclose background and circumstances

Crimes.Violation_Type: Remaining in Canada beyond authorized period
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of officer’s rejection of H&C application
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 25
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, lived without status, applied for H&C relief
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review and re-assessment of H&C claim
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Remained in Canada after visa expiration
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Unusual or disproportionate hardship upon removal
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Personal hardship versus general country conditions
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to conduct individualized hardship analysis
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Duration of stay, family ties, employment, country reports
Crimes.Application_Basis: Request for H&C relief due to integration in Canada
Crimes.Evidence_Assessed: Limited – focused on status rather than personal factors
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Authorization to remain in Canada on H&C grounds
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Section 25 permits relief where unusual hardship would result
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Ignored personal circumstances in favor of generic risks
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Flawed – relied on generalized conditions in Ivory Coast
Crimes.Cause_Description: Overstay led to H&C application after years without status
Crimes.Evidence_Issues: Selective use of evidence favoring refusal
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: No direct fraud, but status non-compliance
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Scope of officer’s discretion under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Focused on illegality rather than compassionate factors
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to meaningfully assess personal hardship

Crimes.Violation_Type: Alleged misuse of marriage for immigration benefit
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reviewable error in hardship assessment under IRPA s.25
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 25
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant lived in Canada without status for years, claimed hardship if returned
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review and re-evaluation of H&C claim
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Remained in Canada unlawfully, sought relief based on ties
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Disproportionate hardship upon return to Ivory Coast
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Community and family ties, length of residence
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay in Canada under H&C provisions
Crimes.Governing_Rule: IRPA Section 25 allows relief in exceptional cases
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of focus on individual circumstances
Crimes.Cause_Description: Seeking H&C relief after years without status and facing removal
Crimes.Evidence_Handling: Did not properly weigh personal factors
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Used incorrect legal test for hardship

Crimes.Crime_Name: Illegal presence in the United States
Crimes.Violation_Type: Unauthorized stay in the U.S. prior to Canadian application
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 25
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant had illegal presence in multiple countries including the U.S.
Crimes.Court_Ruling: Hardship analysis flawed due to reliance on generalized risk
Crimes.Defendant_Behavior: Entered and remained in U.S. illegally before coming to Canada
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Hardship if returned to Ivory Coast
Crimes.Assessment_Factor: Personal hardship and integration in Canada
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Improper use of country condition analysis in H&C context
Crimes.Evidence_Used: History of stays, ties in Canada, country reports
Crimes.Application_Basis: Request for H&C relief based on life in Canada
Crimes.Governing_Rule: Section 25 allows relief where unusual hardship exists
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to assess personal circumstances individually
Crimes.Harm_Assessment: Based on generalized risk, not personal factors
Crimes.Cause_Description: Prior illegal presence contributed to H&C application denial
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant in both U.S. and Canada
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Misapplied legal framework for H&C assessment
Crimes.Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to engage with applicant’s full context

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Failure to comply with removal order leading to H&C application
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reviewable error in hardship assessment under IRPA s.25
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), Section 25
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Partial – establishment reasonably assessed, hardship not
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate unusual hardship
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Diminished by non-compliance with removal order
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 25 H&C relief available despite non-compliance
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for facts, correctness for law
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Length of stay, community ties, country conditions
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA Part 1, Division 3 – Humanitarian and Compassionate
Crimes.Applicant_Challenge: Officer applied wrong test for hardship
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Relied on unauthorized status as basis for refusal
Crimes.Governing_Rule: IRPA Section 25 allows discretion based on compassion
